I know there is plenty of debate about whether Christ was the "Messiah" or just a historical figure, but I just came across this interesting article which presents the argument that no such person ever existed at all.
 
 It presents as evidence the following-
 
 In 1800 BC, King Amunothph of the Nile was described in an engraving as having the exact story as the Gospels tell about Jesus, including the virgin birth, stable cradle, guiding star, massacre of the children, flight to Egypt, resurrection and bodily ascension to the clouds.
 
 This is beside the fact that so many cultures have similar god-child-born-of-virgin myths, including cultures in ancient Babylonia, Egypt, Greece, Rome and Palestine.
 

 
 The idea of Christianity "borrowing" stuff (e.g. the belief that Christianity borrowed from the "mystery religions") like this has been discredited since these sorts of arguments fail upon closer examination due to the similarities being exaggerations and/or oversimplifications. (For instance, one claim that baptism was modeled after a Mithraic cult ceremony, but this ceremony involved slaughtering a bull and bathing in its blood and guts, much too different to infer borrowing here even if it was plausible that Jews would find something attractive about this.) I ran "King Amunothph" through the Internet and was not able to find any information about him except in some web pages claiming that Christianity copied from it. This seems awfully suspicious.
 
 
 

 Contemporaries who wrote from the areas that Jesus is supposed to have been in during the time he was supposedly actively preaching the Gospel and healing multitudes did not find him important enough to mention. 
 

 
 First, we need to recognize there was no TV news network or modern communications systems that we have today. Also, Jesus was a poor peasant worker from an insignificant town who was executed as a common criminal. (Note there are doubtless many crucified people who lived at the time yet we don't know anything about their lives or even their names.) He reportedly healed some people (not "multitudes") and was perhaps an interesting local story via word-of-mouth, but he just wasn't news to the people of the time. Historians then were more concerned with military and political matters. Yes he claimed to be the Messiah, but so did a lot of other radical men. He did not take office, speak in the Roman Senate, write any treatises on philosophy, lead a violent revolt, or anything of the sort. Jesus is famous now, of course, but in the time and area in which he lived there just wasn't a reason for him to be so.
 
 
 

 For example, the great Jewish scholar Philo, who was in Jerusalem at the same time as Jesus was supposedly there, and in all his works he does not even once mention him, even as a "false prophet". 
 

 
 Jesus of Nazareth was not much of a relevant topic in the kinds of things he wrote about even if the carpenter was more newsworthy. He mainly wrote on reconciling Judaism with Greek philosophy. Additionally, he died at around 40 C.E., he just didn't live long enough to see Christianity become much of an influence (unlike Josephus) and in fact never said anything about Christianity.
 
 It should be noted also that the existence of Jesus is no more disputed than Alexander the Great among professional scholars.
 
 
 

 There is also the matter that the way Jesus is described by Paul is very different from the Jesus of the Gospels
 

 
 In what way?
